Posts.Content: Jul 28, 2009 03:42AM Ainm wrote: I'm on the second last day of 15 sessions (dose dense). I was tired before I ever started RT as I had very bad pain and discomfort left over from chemo which I finished just 4 weeks before starting rads.  My chemo was 4AC and 4 Taxol on a 14 day cycle. The AC got to me by the 3 session and two days after my first Taxol I started with severe bone and musle pain which stayed with me right through the 4 sessions and even now I still have residual pain from it.  I see my onc today and he will be starting me on Tamox - I can't imagine ever getting my energy back!!
Posts.Title: RADIATION FATIGUE - POLL bluejay1 Siciliana

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 02:58PM Ainm wrote: Well I was dx at age 45 with DCIS and IDC, multifocal (largest tumor 4.6cm), node involvment, lymphovascular invasion.  My tx was, left side mastectomy, with auxillary clearance, 4 DD AC, 4 DD T, 15 DD Rads with bolus to mast scar every time!! (I say DD rads because anyone else I ever knew who had rads for BC had had at least 30 rads, when I was told I was only getting 15 I was nervous that it would not be enough so I asked the rad onc and he said that I was getting the same dosage as someone who would get 30 rads but over a shorter treatment period 'to maximise the impact'!!!) Now I'm on Tamox.  I wonder what my chances of escaping a recurrence is???

Posts.Content: Sep 28, 2009 11:03AM Ainm wrote: Any advice for really really dry scalp?  I am 15 weeks PFC I have about a half inch of hair, it isn't getting any longer but it has thickened a bit but slowly. I am my own personal snow storm. I oil my scalp before I wash my hair but I only get about a day without 'snow'. If I was in a greenhouse people would think it was a life sized snow globe!!! It's awkward because my hair doesn't look great while it is oiled so I have to do that and then wash it before I can go out - but the longer I leave the oil on the better but then I can't go out!!! SFBC - why do we have to put up with all this!!!

If it's not the mouth wash - well then I'm stumped - haven't a clue what you mean but I'll get my friend in Seattle to send me whatever it is!!!!  Or I could convince my DH that I need to go to NY for hair care products (or oral hygiene products!!).  Thanks for your help, really appreciate it - at the moment I'm dripping almond oil!!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: Oct 21, 2009 04:18PM Ainm wrote: I have about one and a quarter inches of (grey) hair and it's becoming seriously kinked. Very little hair over my forehead which is a real give away that this is regrowth rather than a deliberate short style.  All other hair has returned and my eyelashes didn't fall out anymore. My only problem is a very dry scalp - I've tried almond oil and listerine (as advised) but so far I'm still my very own snow storm!!  I use 'simple' shampoo and I haven't used any other products, colours or conditioners (except for the almond oil and listerine as mentioned).  I went 'topless' quite early on - I didn't realise how sparse my hair was at the time until I saw photos - asked DH why he left me go out like that and he said if I was comfortable with it why not!!  I was dropping my DH at Uni last week and we overheard one guy say to another - 'look, my hair is longer than hers!!'  I like my new hair!!!
Posts.Title: Hair Hair Hair - Another question Deen Krose53

Posts.Content: May 17, 2010 06:13PM Ainm wrote: Barbe - He says that he has flown high but just over houses or tree tops.  He loves it when he's just gliding a foot or two above the ground.  He flies upright, not prone and tilts his body forward to accelerate. His favourite thing is stepping off the top step of a flight of stairs and just gliding to the bottom and 'braking' gently by just putting down his foot.  He said he hasn't experienced touch - for him it's all about being air borne. If anyone is reading this without having read the preceding posts - no I'm not married to superman (well he is to me!!)  we are taking about dream flights!!! LOL

Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 8, 2009 04:36PM Ainm wrote: Dx aged 45 after I noticed a thickening on the top of my left breast. DCIS and IDC, multifocal, largest tumor 4.6cm, lymph nodes involved (one completely blown), lympovascular invasion. Tx Maxtectomy with auxiliary clearance (staph infection after surgery), 4 DD AC, 4 DD T (port inserted after first chemo, got another staph infection, port wasn't used until last chemo). 15 dd Rads with bolus everytime. Now on Tamox - port due to come out on Tuesday. Had very bad reaction to Taxol (onc said only 1 in 50 would have as severe a reaction) was hospitalised twice due to excruciating pain. Still have a lot of muscle and joint pain, numbness in feet. Taking Lyricia to deal with the pain. Have some se's from tamox but they are usually manageable. So would anyone venture what's in my future???
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: May 10, 2010 07:30AM Ainm wrote: I'm 16 months post mx & ALND and I haven't had any problems and hope I will not.  Within a few hours of surgery I was encouraged to start physio on that arm and I did the exercises as directed and I still do some stretching exercises daily and I moisturise that arm regularly. Other than that I don't do anything special - in fact I do everything as I did pre surgery except I would try to remember not to have blood pressure taken (although they did in the hospital) and no needles on that side either. Hope it all turns out well for you.
Posts.Title: Anyone NOT have lymphedemia from lymph removal?? khill Jenniferz

Posts.Content: Jan 22, 2010 05:34PM Ainm wrote: No more tests here either!!  My dr told me the same as yours, Jo. I don't even get blood tests and will just have a mammo on the remaining breast once a year, it is a little un-nerving. I had a mx, chemo and I had rads too - I did have node involvement and LVI. Now I'm on tamox and unlike a lot of the women who post here I was not tested to see if I metabolise Tamox so I don't even know if this is doing me any good. I worry about every ach, pain, lump and bump!!!! I really hope I learn to cope with this sooner tather than later!!!  Hope you will too!!!
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 06:47PM Ainm wrote: Day - You don't have to have a port.  I got one because I had an infection after surgery and I was on strong IV antibiotics for 10 days, by the time I was finished with them my veins were in bad condition and there was no time to let them recover before chemo, hence the port. As it so happens I got an infection in the incision wound adjacent to the port so it was never actually used for my chemo except for the very last one. They use to have a hell of a time trying to get a vein for IV chemo for me and I was DD chemo so the veins had little or no time to recover between doses and as I had node clearance on the side of my mastectomy they had only one arm to work with.  I really think there was a big frowny face on my file because they just hated trying to get an IV site for me - I think they used to have a competition to see who would do me - the loser got me!!! And things haven't changed much - it took them ages to get a vein for a blood test yesterday - even tried my feet - ouch!! If you don't want a port and your veins are normal you will do fine - best of luck, we have similar dx except I was dx in January - you will get through this.
Posts.Title: Stage II w/Lymph Node Involvement Warrior517 Moderators

Posts.Content: Nov 11, 2009 05:02PM Ainm wrote: Another milestone for me - had my port out yesterday!!! Even got a bit weepy about it. Discovered that I'm still quite jumpy about things - there was a long delay at the hospital between them taking blood and actually taking the port out (really long - hours) and I started to panic thinking that maybe 'something' had shown up in my blood!!! Silly I know but I am just so uneasy about all this still. Took it easy today as I was a bit achy and sore, more than I expected. Next milestone will be my first PFC mammo and onc visit in Jan (exactly one year to the day of my mastectomy). Hope everyone keeps sharing their experiences.

Posts.Title: What a feeling!! geewhiz MaxineO

Posts.Content: Jan 21, 2010 05:10PM Ainm wrote: Well I'm over the first year!! There hasn't been a day in that year that I haven't thought about BC, I cried most days, ranted most days, felt angry, felt sorry for myself but I tried to be strong, positive and pro active too - and it's sooooo hard and I really surprised myself!!  I still worry and am disappointed that it hasn't all just fizzled out - it's still very much in my face but I got through the year - mx surgery, staph infections DD AC, DD Taxol (bad se's) DD rads, port problems when it was being put in and again when it was being taken out!!!, baldness, hair regrowth, the disappearance of sleep, hate the foob!!, stupid comments from well meaning people, tamoxifen and a host of se's from chemo and tamox - but I got through the year  -- with your help - thank you!!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Jan 10, 2010 11:17PM Ainm wrote: My lump was 4.6 cm my BS recommended a mastectomy and lymph node removal - nodes were involved and I had lympovascular invasion so I had DD chemo and rads after surgery.  I still worry about recurrence but I guess that may ease with time. Today I heard that a friend of mine who was diagnosed about 3 months before me has had a recurrence in the same breast and has had to have a mastectomy - she had a lumpectomy first time round (she is triple neg though) but now I think at least with a mastectomy that shouldn't happen me.  Physically I recoved very well from the mastectomy and because I had rads I haven't had any reconstruction - that's another days work - but it is a very visible and constant reminder of what has happened you would have to be strong and get your head around that.  As in most things that I have to make a decision about I normally get out a sheet of paper draw a line down the middle and do a list of pros on one side and cons on the other - it may sound trite but it does help.  Best of luck and remember there are some wonderful people on these forums who are great support so visit often - I don't know what I would do without the support of this forum.

Posts.Content: Oct 30, 2009 06:02PM Ainm wrote: I noticed from those of you who post your diagnosis that the 'oldest' posted was 2005 - are there any 'older' stage ll'er's out there??  I was diagnosed in Jan this year and am still really nervous about the chance of recurrence - yes that elephant in the room - it would be great to hear how others have dealt with this? How do you compartmentalise this fear and put it in the background - does it just happen automatically as time goes on??  I am really, really trying to lose weigh ( I am very over weight) and I am trying to build some exercise into my daily routine but I wonder a) am I doing enough and b) will I be able to keep it up. I would love to hear others hints and tips.  It is good to have a stage ll thread!!!!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 05:59PM - edited Oct 27, 2009 06:00PM by Ainm Shanagirl, We were both dx about the same time and I am finding it quite hard to accept that I have not been "cured" too.  I know that every treatment I had/have will improve my chances of escaping recurrence and I've had mastectomy, chemo, rads and now on Tamoxifen but, and this is the big BUT, no one can guarantee me 'it' will not come back.  I try to reason with myself and say well if I had a heart attack no one would guarantee me that  I wouldn't die of a heart attack but I guess if that was my situation I might be just as fearful as I am in my present situation anyway. I was speaking to a lady who had been dx 19 years ago and she said that although you can never totally forget what might happen she has found that generally she can put it to the back of her mind - when she hears or reads about someone who has had a recurrence - she takes out her fear dusts it off, says 'not yet' and puts it back to the back of her mind again!!! Maybe I'll be like that in 19 years time but now, 10 months after dx, I am too raw and fearful to even imagine that I'll make 19 years!!  I'm not being negative - just honest and scared!! I have joined a BC support group in the hopes that I might find the tools to help myself get beyond this.  It's good to be able to talk to like minded women and I found that most of those I spoke to who were recently dx (upto 2 years ) are still quite fearful of recurrence - I was happy to find I wasn't alone in this!!  So Shanagirl - you are most definitely not alone!!
Posts.Title: THE REALITY OF IT ALL Shanagirl Pure

Posts.Content: Oct 27, 2009 05:19PM Ainm wrote: I was wondering about this too. Count me in!!
Posts.Title: Stage II Forum rumoret NativeMainer

Posts.Content: Oct 31, 2009 05:56PM Ainm wrote: Valerie and Terry, thank you so much for your replies.  I do make an effort not to dwell on the fact that I have had a cancer dx.  But on numerous occasions everyday it comes to the fore. Sometimes it is highlighted because of the left over se's from chemo or se's from Tamoxifen.  There are so many reminders - hair growing back, lack of sleep, taking medication - it's hard to get away from it.  I still cry for the least reason.  As I said I am exercising and dieting and this also serves as a reminder - I feel deprived of one of my favourite things - FOOD!!! I try not to let my insecurities be apparent to those around me although DH knows and is very supportive, but it is very hard to smile through it all.  Terry I take your point about the forums - I spend hours scouring the boards for any thread I can identify with - maybe I should cut back on it.  And I know what you mean when you say about hearing about others who get a cancer dx.  I also noticed that quite often when people ask me how I am they also seem to be compelled to tell me about others who have cancer - people I don't know at all!!  And of course cancer related deaths are hard too. A friends sister died a few weeks ago. She had been dx with BC 10 years ago and had a recurrence resulting in her death. When I went to sympathise with her mother she said 'but you'll be fine' - it just set me off and once out of hearing I needed my DH to assure me that I would indeed get more than 10 years out of all this fiasco - irrationality working overtime!!! Hmm - the Oncotype test is only being trialled in Ireland at present so we have to rely on the expertise and experiences of our drs still.  I ended up with mx, 4 DD AC, 4 DD T, 15 DD rads and Tamoxifen (with two bouts of staph thrown in for good measure!!) - really hope this has annihilated the damn cancer. It's great to see all the people who are joining in on this thread and Lisa it's really good to see you here as an older stage ll'er!!.
